sen.j: 川端 茅舎（かわばた ぼうしゃ、1897年8月17日 - 1941年7月17日）は、東京都日本橋蛎殻町出身の日本の俳人、画家。
sen.e: Bosha KAWABATA (August 17, 1897 - July 17, 1941) was a Japanese haiku poet and painter who was born at Nihonbashi Kakigara-cho, Tokyo Prefecture.
Bosha KAWABATA (August 17, 1897 - July 17, 1941) was a Japanese haiku poet and painter who was from Nihonbashi Kakigara-cho, Tokyo Prefecture.
sen.cmt: was born at を fromに変更しました。
sen.e: Bosha KAWABATA (August 17, 1897 - July 17, 1941) was a Japanese haiku poet and painter who was from Nihonbashi Kakigara-cho, Tokyo Prefecture.

sen.j: 日本画である川端龍子とは異母弟。
sen.e: Ryushi KAWABATA, a Japanese-style painter, was his half-brother.
sen.cmt: 原文の「日本画」は「日本画家」、「異母弟」は「異母兄弟」ととりました。
sen.e: Ryushi KAWABATA, a Japanese-style painter, was his half-brother.
Ryushi KAWABATA, a Japanese-style painter, was his maternal half-brother.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせ maternal half-brotherとしました。

sen.j: 本名は川端信一（かわばた のぶかず）。
sen.e: His real name was Nobukazu KAWABATA.
His real name was Nobukazu KAWABATA.
His real name was Nobukazu KAWABATA.

sen.j: 別号、遊牧の民・俵屋春光。
sen.e: His other pseudonyms are "Yuboku no Tami" (Nomadic Person) and "Shunko TAWARAYA".
His other pseudonyms are "Yuboku no Tami" (Nomadic Person) and "Shunko TAWARAYA".
His other pseudonyms are "Yuboku no Tami" (Nomadic Person) and "Shunko TAWARAYA".

sen.j: 高浜虚子に師事し、虚子に『花鳥諷詠真骨頂漢』とまで言わしめたホトトギス派・写生派の俳人。
sen.e: He was a poet of Hototogisu (the traditional haiku style) and shasei ("sketching") haiku and a pupil of Kyoshi TAKAHAMA, who called him "Kachofuei Shinkoccho Kan" (a man who shows a perfect exemplar of his art of very objective description on nature).

He was a poet of Hototogisu (the traditional haiku style) and shasei ("sketching") haiku and a pupil of Kyoshi TAKAHAMA, who called him "Kachofuei Shinkoccho Kan" (a man who shows a perfect exemplar of his art of very objective description on nature).

He was a poet of Hototogisu (the traditional haiku style) and shasei ("sketching") haiku and a pupil of Kyoshi TAKAHAMA, who called him "Kachofuei Shinkoccho Kan" (a man who shows a perfect exemplar of his art of very objective description on nature).

sen.j: 仏教用語を駆使したり、凛然とし朗々たる独特な句風は、茅舎の句を『茅舎浄土』と呼ばしめる。
sen.e: With many Buddhist words being employed and his verse style so commanding, sonorous, and unique, his poems were called "Bosha Jodo" (Bosha's Pure Land).
With many Buddhist words being employed and his verse style so commanding, sonorous, and unique, his poems were called "Bosha Jodo" (Bosha's Pure Land).
With many Buddhist words being employed and his verse style so commanding, sonorous, and unique, his poems were called "Bosha Jodo" (Bosha's Pure Land).

sen.j: 1897年、東京都日本橋区蛎殻町で生まれた茅舎は、腹違いの兄である龍子とともに育てられる。
sen.e: Born in 1897, at Nihonbashi Kakigara-cho, Tokyo Prefecture, Bosha was raised with his stepbrother, Ryushi.
Bosha was born in 1897, at Nihonbashi Kakigara-cho, Tokyo Prefecture, and was raised with his stepbrother, Ryushi.
sen.cmt: 自然な流れになるように文全体を訂正しました。
sen.e: Bosha was born in 1897, at Nihonbashi Kakigara-cho, Tokyo Prefecture, and was raised with his stepbrother, Ryushi.

sen.j: 父信吉は紀州藩の下級武士、母は信吉の弟が経営する病院の看護婦。
sen.e: His father, Nobukichi, was a lower-ranking samurai of the Kishu Domain, and his mother worked as a nurse at a hospital, which was run by Nobukichi's younger brother.
His father, Nobukichi, was a lower-ranking samurai of the Kishu Domain, and his mother worked as a nurse at a hospital, which was run by Nobukichi's younger brother.
His father, Nobukichi, was a lower-ranking samurai of the Kishu Domain, and his mother worked as a nurse at a hospital, which was run by Nobukichi's younger brother.

sen.j: 父は弟の病院で手伝いとして働いていたが、その後煙草の小売商を始める。
sen.e: His father worked as an assistant at his brother's hospital before he opened a retail tobacco store.
His father worked as an assistant at his brother's hospital before he opened a retail tobacco store.
His father worked as an assistant at his brother's hospital before he opened a retail tobacco store.

sen.j: 父は「寿山堂」という雅号を自分で持つほど、俳句や日本画や写経を好むような風流人であったと、ホトトギス (雑誌)の中で茅舎は述べている。
sen.e: Bosha had written in the Hototogisu magazine that his father was a man with such a refined taste in haiku poems, Japanese-style paintings, and hand-copying of Sutra script, who even had a pseudonym "Jusando" himself.

Bosha had written in the Hototogisu magazine that his father was a man with such a refined taste in haiku poems, Japanese-style paintings, and hand-copying of Sutra script, who even had a pseudonym "Jusando" himself.

Bosha had written in the Hototogisu magazine that his father was a man with such a refined taste in haiku poems, Japanese-style paintings, and hand-copying of Sutra script, who even had a pseudonym "Jusando" himself.

sen.j: そのことから、茅舎と龍子の兄弟が進むべき道に大きく父親が影響したと考えられている。
sen.e: Therefore, it is considered his father had a great influence on the career paths that the brothers of Bosha and Ryushi would take.
Therefore, it is considered his father had a great influence on the career paths that the brothers of Bosha and Ryushi would take.
Therefore, it is considered his father had a great influence on the career paths that the brothers of Bosha and Ryushi would take.

sen.j: 6歳になった茅舎は、1903年私立有隣代用小学校へ入れられる。
sen.e: After turning 6 years old, Bosha was sent to the Private Yurin Substitute Elementary School in 1903.
After turning 6 years old, Bosha was sent to the Private Yurin Substitute Elementary School in 1903.
After turning 6 years old, Bosha was sent to the Private Yurin Substitute Elementary School in 1903.

sen.j: 無事小学校を卒業した茅舎は、1909年、獨逸学協会学校（のちの獨協中学校）へ入学。
sen.e: After graduating from the elementary school, and Bosha entered the School of the Society for German Studies (the present Dokkyo Junior High School).
After graduating from the elementary school, Bosha entered the School of the Society for German Studies (the present Dokkyo Junior High School).
sen.cmt: and 不要のため削除しました。
sen.e: After graduating from the elementary school, Bosha entered the School of the Society for German Studies (the present Dokkyo Junior High School).

sen.j: 叔父と母が病院に勤める関係者であったことから、周囲から（特に父から）将来は医者になることを期待されていた。
sen.e: Because his mother and uncle worked at a hospital, he was expected by those around him, especially his father, to become a doctor one day.
Because his mother and uncle worked at a hospital, he was expected by those around him, especially his father, to become a doctor one day.
Because his mother and uncle worked at a hospital, he was expected by those around him, especially his father, to become a doctor one day.

sen.j: その後、第一高等学校理乙を受験するも失敗。
sen.e: However, when he later took an entrance examination for entry into science and German program at the Daiichi High School, he failed.
However, when he later took an entrance examination for entry into science and German program at the Daiichi High School, he failed.
However, when he later took an entrance examination for entry into science and German program at the Daiichi High School, he failed.

sen.j: そのころには画家として独立していた兄・龍子の後を追うように、次第に茅舎自身も画家を志すようになる。
sen.e: He seemed to follow the path taken by his brother, who had been self-supporting as a painter by then, gradually setting his heart on becoming a painter himself.
He seemed to follow the path taken by his brother, who had been self-supporting as a painter by then, gradually setting his heart on becoming a painter himself.
He seemed to follow the path taken by his brother, who had been self-supporting as a painter by then, gradually setting his heart on becoming a painter himself.

sen.j: 藤島武二絵画研究所で絵画の勉強を始める。
sen.e: He starts taking painting lessons at the Takeji FUJISHIMA Institute of Painting.
He starts taking painting lessons at the Takeji FUJISHIMA Institute of Painting.
He starts taking painting lessons at the Takeji FUJISHIMA Institute of Painting.

sen.j: また17歳頃から、自らの俳号を「茅舎」と名乗り始め、父とともに句作するようになる。
sen.e: Also, at around 17 years of age, he began using "Bosha" as his haiku pen name and writing haiku poems with his father.
Also, at around 17 years of age, he began using "Bosha" as his haiku pen name and writing haiku poems with his father.
Also, at around 17 years of age, he began using "Bosha" as his haiku pen name and writing haiku poems with his father.

sen.j: 俳句雑誌『キララ』（後の『雲母』）に度々投句する。
sen.e: He repeatedly submitted his poems to a haiku magazine "Kirara" (later called "Unbo").
He repeatedly submitted his poems to a haiku magazine "Kirara" (later called "Unbo").
He repeatedly submitted his poems to a haiku magazine "Kirara" (later called "Unbo").

sen.j: （武者小路実篤の「新しき村」の第二種会員になり、白樺派の思想に触れた茅舎は次第に西洋思想に感化されていく。
sen.e: Bosha he became a second-type member of Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI's "New Village", which introduced the thought of the "Shirakabaha" (White Birch Group) to him, and he would gradually become influenced by Western thought.
sen.cmt: 原文の「（」は誤りと思われます。
sen.e: Bosha became a second-type member of Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI's "New Village", which introduced the thought of the "Shirakabaha" (White Birch Group) to him, and he would gradually become influenced by Western thought.
sen.cmt: he 不要のため削除しました。
sen.e: Bosha became a second-type member of Saneatsu MUSHANOKOJI's "New Village", which introduced the thought of the "Shirakabaha" (White Birch Group) to him, and he would gradually become influenced by Western thought.

sen.j: それが契機で、絵画の分野で明確に西洋絵画を志すようになり、その後洋画家岸田劉生に画を師事する。
sen.e: That brought him to pursue Western painting in the field of painting, and he became a pupil of a Western-style painter, Ryusei KISHIDA.
That brought him to pursue Western painting in the field of painting, and he became a pupil of a Western-style painter, Ryusei KISHIDA.
That brought him to pursue Western painting in the field of painting, and he became a pupil of a Western-style painter, Ryusei KISHIDA.

sen.j: 京都府の東福寺の正覚庵に籠もり、絵や句の制作に勤しみ、同時に仏道に参じる。
sen.e: Staying at Shogaku-an, a sub-temple of Tofuku-ji Temple in Kyoto Prefecture, he diligently produced paintings and haiku poems and, at the same time, worshipped Buddha.
Staying at Shogaku-an, a sub-temple of Tofuku-ji Temple in Kyoto Prefecture, he diligently produced paintings and haiku poems and, at the same time, worshipped Buddha.
Staying at Shogaku-an, a sub-temple of Tofuku-ji Temple in Kyoto Prefecture, he diligently produced paintings and haiku poems and, at the same time, worshipped Buddha.

sen.j: 自身が描いた静物画が春陽会に入選するほど絵画の腕を上げる。
sen.e: His painting skill improved dramatically, and his still-life painting was accepted for the Shunyo-kai art exhibition.
His painting skill improved dramatically, and his still-life painting was accepted for the Shunyo-kai art exhibition.
His painting skill improved dramatically, and his still-life painting was accepted for the Shunyo-kai art exhibition.

sen.j: しかし虚子門や脊椎カリエスや結核といった肺患に身体が蝕まれていき、師と尊崇していた劉生も死去してしまったこともあり、俳諧の道へ本格的に専念するようになる。
sen.e: But lung diseases such as spinal caries and tuberculosis began to undermine his body, and Ryusei, whom Bosha respected as his mater, passed away, bringing him to seriously focus on the field of haikai (a popular style of Japanese linked verse).
sen.cmt: 原文の「虚子門」とは、高浜虚子門のことで、肺患とは関係ないと思われます。
sen.e: But lung diseases such as spinal caries and tuberculosis began to undermine his body, and Ryusei, whom Bosha respected as his mater, passed away, bringing him to seriously focus on the field of haikai (a popular style of Japanese linked verse).

But lung diseases such as spinal caries and tuberculosis began to undermine his body, and Ryusei, whom Bosha respected as his mater, passed away, bringing him to seriously focus on the field of haikai (a popular style of Japanese linked verse).

sen.j: 投句を続けていた『キララ』から『ホトトギス (雑誌)』に専念的に投句をし始め、雑詠の巻頭を飾るまでになる。
sen.e: Instead of sending his haiku poems to "Kirara", which he had continued until then, he began to concentrate on the "Hototogisu" haiku magazine to send his poems, and his poem appeared on the opening page of the magazine.

Instead of sending his haiku poems to "Kirara", which he had continued until then, he began to concentrate on the "Hototogisu" haiku magazine to send his poems, and his poem appeared on the opening page of the magazine.

Instead of sending his haiku poems to "Kirara", which he had continued until then, he began to concentrate on the "Hototogisu" haiku magazine to send his poems, and his poem appeared on the opening page of the magazine.

sen.j: その後、高浜虚子の愛弟子となり、俳句の実力が認められ、1934年に『ホトトギス』の同人となる。
sen.e: After that, he became a beloved pupil of Kyoshi TAKAHAMA, and, with his talent being recognized, he became a member of the" Hototogisu" group in 1934.
After that, he became a beloved pupil of Kyoshi TAKAHAMA, and, with his talent being recognized, he became a member of the" Hototogisu" group in 1934.
After that, he became a beloved pupil of Kyoshi TAKAHAMA, and, with his talent being recognized, he became a member of the" Hototogisu" group in 1934.

sen.j: また後に「あをぎり句会」の選者となる
sen.e: Later, he also became a member of the Aogiri Haiku Group selection committee.
Later, he also became a member of the Aogiri Haiku Group selection committee.
Later, he also became a member of the Aogiri Haiku Group selection committee.

sen.j: 1941年、肺患の悪化により44歳の若さで死去。
sen.e: In 1941, his lung diseases worsened, and he passed away at the early age of 44.
In 1941, his lung diseases worsened, and he passed away at the early age of 44.
In 1941, his lung diseases worsened, and he passed away at the early age of 44.

sen.j: 現在は、龍子や他の家族とともに伊豆の修善寺に埋葬されている。
sen.e: He now rests at the Shuzen-ji Temple on the Izu Peninsula, with Ryushi and other family members.
He now rests at the Shuzen-ji Temple on the Izu Peninsula, with Ryushi and other family members.
He now rests at the Shuzen-ji Temple on the Izu Peninsula, with Ryushi and other family members.

sen.j: 西洋的な感性と東洋的な感性で紡ぎ出された写生的な句は、花鳥諷詠を唱えた虚子に「花鳥諷詠真骨頂漢」と評価されるほどであった。
sen.e: His haiku poems in the pictorial shasei style were spun with his Western and Eastern sensibilities, and they were so brilliant that Kyoshi, who advocated the ideology of Kachofuei (very objective description on nature), called him "Kachofuei Shinkoccho Kan" (a man who shows a perfect exemplar of his art of Kachofuei).

His haiku poems in the pictorial shasei style were spun with his Western and Eastern sensibilities, and they were so brilliant that Kyoshi, who advocated the ideology of Kachofuei (very objective description on nature), called him "Kachofuei Shinkoccho Kan" (a man who shows a perfect exemplar of his art of Kachofuei).

His haiku poems in the pictorial shasei style were spun with his Western and Eastern sensibilities, and they were so brilliant that Kyoshi, who advocated the ideology of Kachofuei (very objective description on nature), called him "Kachofuei Shinkoccho Kan" (a man who shows a perfect exemplar of his art of Kachofuei).

sen.j: 『川端茅舎句集』（1934年）
